Defendant whose motion to suppress was recommended for denial by the Magistrate Judge and who appeared to concede that the route taken would be convenient for smugglers, testified in a hearing about his vehicle not going off the road
Defendant whose involuntary transportation to the Border Patrol station for questioning was deemed 'sufficiently like an arrest' and required probable cause, exhibited extreme nervousness during a traffic stop, and provided inconsistent statements about the vehicle's ownership
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.RICARDO RODRIGUEZ, JR. and IGNACIO RODRI: Defendants whose motions to suppress were recommended for denial by the Magistrate Judge
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jorge Luis Trevino: United States Border Patrol Agent who testified about road conditions during a hearing, specifically regarding Farm-to-Market Road 2050, and explained vehicle encounters, noted an observation of Ricardo Rodriguez's vehicle, testified during cross examination, approached a car with five passengers which was riding low due to the number of people, followed the black truck for around five minutes noticing it going often off the shoulder
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Rodriguez: Individual involved in the incident, referred to as Ignacio Rodriguez
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Agent Rodriguez: United States Border Patrol Agent who alerted to the two vehicles, likely referring to Rodriguez
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Agent Trevino: United States Border Patrol Agent who testified regarding traffic patterns on FM 2050 and about the black truck having a dark blue or black camper, followed the vehicles around 6:00 p.m. and caught up to them ten miles down FM 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jorge Luis Trevino and Rodriguez: Border Patrol agents involved in the investigation of suspicious vehicles on FM 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mills Bennett: Involved in the case, mentioned during the cross examination of Agent Trevino, associated with a dirt road near the checkpoint
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Reymundo Reyes: Law enforcement officer who conducted a traffic stop of Ignacio Rodriguez and issued a citation, later impounded the vehicle due to lack of insurance information and uncertainty about the vehicle's ownership
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. and Jorge Luis Tr: Individuals involved in the case, with Ignacio Rodriguez as a defendant and Jorge Luis Trevino as a United States Border Patrol Agent
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hugo Benavides: United States Border Patrol Agent who transported Ignacio Rodriguez to the checkpoint for further questioning
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mr. Rodriguez: Defendant stopped by Officer Reyes, driver of the vehicle, transported to a checkpoint for further questioning
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Agent Benavides: United States Border Patrol Agent who testified about arrest and had subjective belief on probable cause for making an arrest
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Marco Montemayor: Special Agent who conducted an interview with Ignacio Rodriguez after he waived his Miranda rights, described the beginning of the interview and ensured that Ignacio Rodriguez understood his rights
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Marco Montemayor and his partner: Agents who interviewed Ignacio Rodriguez after he waived his Miranda rights
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Ricardo Rodriguez: Defendant stopped near the Mexico border, driver of a white sedan, who appeared to concede that the route taken would be convenient for smugglers, testified in a hearing about his vehicle not going off the road, and qualified his testimony with statements such as "I'm pretty sure it did not" and "I don't . . . think I got off the road"
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Ignacio Rodriguez: Potential arrest subject, defendant stopped by Officer Reyes, exhibited extreme nervousness during a traffic stop
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jorge Luis Trevino and IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ: Border Patrol agents involved in the investigation of suspicious vehicles on FM 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hugo Benavides in CHUNK_TEXT: United States Border Patrol Agent who questioned Defendant at the Border Patrol station and did not corroborate Agent Trevino's testimony about the black truck having a camper
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. in CHUNK_TEXT: Defendant whose involuntary transportation to the Border Patrol station for questioning was deemed 'sufficiently like an arrest' and required probable cause
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.J. Scott Hacker: United States Magistrate Judge who signed the document, took judicial notice of the fact that the sun set at 6:22 p.m. on February 4, 2013 in Laredo, Texas, does not consider the vehicle's low ride height as contributing to reasonable suspicion for a stop
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.RICARDO RODRIGUEZ, JR. in CHUNK_TEXT: Defendant whose involuntary transportation to the Border Patrol station for questioning was deemed 'sufficiently like an arrest' and required probable cause
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Officer Reyes: Law enforcement officer who impounded the vehicle due to lack of insurance information and uncertainty about the vehicle's ownership
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Reyes: Testifying officer, referred to as Officer Reyes
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Alberto Ramirez: Director of Transportation, Planning and Development for the Texas Department of Transportation, Laredo Division, testified about traffic flow data on FM 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Santiago Hinojosa: Manager with the Hertz rental car company at the Laredo International Airport who testified that it was not unusual to rent a car from one location that is registered to another city or state
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Orona-Sanchez: Individual referenced in a court finding regarding alien smuggling using pickup trucks with camper shells
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the Defendants: Defendants whose driving was considered an aberration from the norm by Agent Trevino
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jorge Luis Trevino in CHUNK_TEXT: United States Border Patrol Agent stationed at the Freer immigration checkpoint, inspecting vehicles and processing undocumented individuals, followed the black truck for around five minutes noticing it going often off the shoulder
